steps.story: At first it meant slowness.  Over time it became the name of the day’s slow part, when the sun begins to fall.  Spanish kept both meanings inside one sound.
steps.wrap_line: ‘Tarde’ is the slow gold of the day — time that lingers.

steps.line: Use it easily: 'Trabajo en la tarde.'  'Llego tarde.'  Same word, two ideas — the time and the feeling of it.

steps.title: Nombre / Padre / Chico — Name, Father, Boy
steps.description: Three short lessons that stay inside familiar grammar and vocabulary. Each word connects directly to things learners already say every day.

steps.line: Name.
‘Nombre’ means name — the sound that identifies you.  It’s the word you use with 'me llamo' and in simple introductions.

steps.origin: From Latin 'nomen' — name.
steps.story: Spanish kept the link between naming and calling.  'Nombre' is what you carry, but 'me llamo' is how you use it.
steps.wrap_line: ‘Nombre’ is identity written in sound.

steps.line: Say: 'Mi nombre es Ray.' / 'Tu nombre es Ana.' / 'El nombre es largo.'
Father.
‘Padre’ means father — formal and respectful.  It names the person, not the feeling.

steps.origin: From Latin 'pater' — father.
steps.story: In Spanish, 'padre' can mean both parent and priest, both care and authority.  It’s the solid center of family.
steps.wrap_line: ‘Padre’ is the pillar word — strong and steady.

steps.line: Say: 'Mi padre trabaja.' / 'El padre está en la casa.'
Boy. Guy.
‘Chico’ means boy, guy, or young man.  It’s casual and friendly, used in everyday talk.

steps.origin: From Old Spanish 'chico' — small, young.
steps.story: It began as an affectionate word for 'small one' and still keeps that light tone today.
steps.wrap_line: ‘Chico’ is youth in sound — small, quick, alive.

steps.line: Say: 'El chico camina.' / 'El chico es bueno.'

steps.title: Lugar / Sentimiento / Chica / Casa / Izquierda — Place, Feeling, Girl, House, Left
steps.description: Five short lessons that describe place, emotion, people, home, and direction — all with safe vocabulary already installed.

steps.line: Place.
‘Lugar’ means place — any space where something or someone is.  It’s the word you use when you talk about being or going somewhere.

steps.origin: From Latin 'locare' — to place, to put.
steps.story: Spanish uses it for both real and imagined spaces: a house, a city, a moment in time.  Every 'lugar' holds a story.
steps.wrap_line: ‘Lugar’ is space made personal.

steps.line: Say: 'Estoy en un lugar bueno.' / 'Voy a un lugar nuevo.'
Feeling.
‘Sentimiento’ is what lives inside — an emotion or sensation.  It comes from the verb 'sentir,' to feel.

steps.origin: From Latin 'sentire' — to perceive, to feel.
steps.story: In Spanish, feelings are things you can almost touch.  They belong to people and to art: 'un sentimiento bonito' — a beautiful feeling.
steps.wrap_line: ‘Sentimiento’ is emotion turned into matter.

steps.line: Say: 'Tengo un sentimiento feliz.' / 'El sentimiento es fuerte.'
Girl.
‘Chica’ is the feminine pair of 'chico.'  It means girl or young woman — casual, friendly, and warm.

steps.origin: From Old Spanish 'chico/chica' — small, young.
steps.story: The word still carries tenderness.  It can mean child or just a person younger or smaller than you.
steps.wrap_line: ‘Chica’ is youth in a softer sound.

steps.line: Say: 'La chica camina.' / 'La chica está feliz.'
House. Home.
‘Casa’ is the physical home — the building itself.  It pairs with 'hogar' (the feeling of home) from before.

steps.origin: From Latin 'casa' — hut or cottage.
steps.story: In Spanish, 'casa' can be tiny or grand.  It always means shelter, a place where life happens.
steps.wrap_line: ‘Casa’ is the word for walls that protect you.

steps.line: Say: 'Estoy en la casa.' / 'La casa es grande.'
Left.
‘Izquierda’ is the direction opposite 'derecha' (right).  It helps you move or describe where things are.

steps.origin: From Basque 'ezker' — left side.
steps.story: Spanish borrowed the sound long ago.  The word feels heavy and soft, like the slower hand.
steps.wrap_line: ‘Izquierda’ is the quiet side of direction.

steps.line: Say: 'Gira a la izquierda.' / 'La puerta está a la izquierda.'

steps.title: Derecha / Madre / Curso / Papá / Mundo — Right, Mother, Course, Dad, World
steps.description: Five everyday nouns that finish the family and direction pairs and add common life words used in daily talk.

steps.line: Right.
‘Derecha’ is the direction opposite 'izquierda.'  It guides you when giving or following simple routes.

steps.origin: From Latin 'directus' — straight, direct.
steps.story: The same root gives English 'direct.'  In Spanish, 'derecha' is both the right-hand side and the symbol of correctness.
steps.wrap_line: ‘Derecha’ is the word for the clear, straight side.

steps.line: Say: 'Gira a la derecha.' / 'El mercado está a la derecha.'
Mother.
‘Madre’ means mother — the formal, tender word for the person who gives life and care.

steps.origin: From Latin 'mater' — mother.
steps.story: Spanish treats 'madre' as both everyday and sacred.  You hear it in thanks, in songs, and in family talk.
steps.wrap_line: ‘Madre’ is the first home you ever had — turned into sound.

steps.line: Say: 'Mi madre está en la casa.' / 'La madre es buena.'
Course. Class.
‘Curso’ means course, both as a class you take and as a flow or direction of learning.

steps.origin: From Latin 'cursus' — running, path.
steps.story: A 'curso' is like a river of knowledge — something that moves and carries you.  Spanish keeps that sense of movement in education.
steps.wrap_line: ‘Curso’ is learning in motion.

steps.line: Say: 'Estoy en un curso.' / 'El curso es bueno.'
Dad.
‘Papá’ is the warm, familiar version of 'padre.'  It’s what children and family say at home.

steps.origin: From early child speech in many languages — an easy first sound, kept in almost every culture.
steps.story: Spanish treats 'papá' with affection and informality.  It’s not only family; it’s comfort.
steps.wrap_line: ‘Papá’ is the everyday love word for father.

steps.line: Say: 'Mi papá trabaja.' / 'Papá está feliz.'
World.
‘Mundo’ means world — the big space that holds every place and every person.

steps.origin: From Latin 'mundus' — universe, order.
steps.story: In Spanish, 'mundo' carries both geography and humanity: 'todo el mundo' means everyone.  It joins people into one idea.
steps.wrap_line: ‘Mundo’ is the shared house of all lives.

steps.line: Say: 'El mundo es grande.' / 'Vivo en el mundo bueno.'

steps.title: Hijo / Coche / Mujer / Amigo / Mente — Son, Car, Woman, Friend, Mind
steps.description: Five short lessons about people, travel, and thought. Each word connects naturally to verbs and adjectives already learned.

steps.line: Son.
‘Hijo’ means son — the child of a mother or father.  It connects family generations in one word.

steps.origin: From Latin 'filius' — child, son.
steps.story: Spanish keeps the emotional closeness of the word.  'Mi hijo' means 'my son' — simple and full of care.
steps.wrap_line: ‘Hijo’ is family spoken softly.

steps.line: Say: 'Mi hijo está en la casa.' / 'El hijo es bueno.'
Car.
‘Coche’ means car.  Some countries say 'auto,' others 'carro' — all mean the same thing: a vehicle for going places.

steps.origin: From old word 'cocho' — carriage or coach.
steps.story: In Spain, 'coche' is standard; in Latin America, 'auto' or 'carro' works too.  For now, just remember it’s motion made of metal.
steps.wrap_line: ‘Coche’ is the word for movement with wheels.

steps.line: Say: 'Voy en coche.' / 'El coche es grande.'
Woman.
‘Mujer’ means woman — the adult feminine word.  It can mean wife when context makes it clear.

steps.origin: From Latin 'mulier' — woman.
steps.story: The word kept its original dignity.  You’ll hear it in daily speech and literature alike: 'la mujer trabaja,' 'una mujer fuerte.'
steps.wrap_line: ‘Mujer’ is strength said gently.

steps.line: Say: 'La mujer trabaja.' / 'La mujer está en la casa.'
Friend.
‘Amigo’ means friend.  Add 'a' for 'amiga' when speaking about a girl.  It’s one of the most loved Spanish words.

steps.origin: From Latin 'amicus' — friendly, beloved.
steps.story: Spanish keeps friendship close to love: 'amigo' comes from the same family as 'amor' (love).  It’s a simple, generous word.
steps.wrap_line: ‘Amigo / amiga’ means chosen family.

steps.line: Say: 'Mi amigo está aquí.' / 'Mi amiga es feliz.'
Mind.
‘Mente’ means mind — the part of you that thinks and dreams.  It pairs with words like 'pensamiento.'

steps.origin: From Latin 'mens' — mind, spirit.
steps.story: In Spanish, mind and feeling often mix.  You can say 'tengo la mente tranquila' — I have a calm mind.  It’s not only logic; it’s peace.
steps.wrap_line: ‘Mente’ is the quiet room inside your head.

steps.line: Say: 'La mente es fuerte.' / 'Tengo la mente feliz.'

steps.title: Cabeza / Mamá / Niño / Trabajo / Bebé — Head, Mom, Child, Work, Baby
steps.description: Five short story-based lessons about body, family, work, and care. Each one connects to actions and feelings from earlier levels.

steps.line: Head.
‘Cabeza’ means head — the top, the part that thinks and sees.  It also appears in expressions about intelligence or calm.

steps.origin: From Latin 'capitia' — the top or beginning of something.
steps.story: Spanish uses 'cabeza' for both the body and for ideas.  Someone who leads a group is also 'la cabeza' — the head.
steps.wrap_line: ‘Cabeza’ is where ideas and direction start.

steps.line: Say: 'Tengo la cabeza tranquila.' / 'La cabeza es parte del cuerpo.'
Mom.
‘Mamá’ is the familiar, loving form of 'madre.'  It’s how you call your mother at home — soft and close.

steps.origin: From baby language sounds found across cultures.
steps.story: It’s one of the first words humans learn.  In Spanish it’s full of affection and safety.
steps.wrap_line: ‘Mamá’ is love said out loud.

steps.line: Say: 'Mi mamá está en la casa.' / 'Mamá es buena.'
Child. Boy. Girl.
‘Niño’ means child or boy; 'niña' is the feminine form.  They describe young people, not babies yet.

steps.origin: From Latin 'ninus' — small one.
steps.story: Spanish loves these words.  They can mean innocence, curiosity, or joy.  You hear them in families and songs.
steps.wrap_line: ‘Niño / niña’ is the word for small life in motion.

steps.line: Say: 'El niño está feliz.' / 'La niña camina.'
Work. Job.
‘Trabajo’ is both the action of working and the thing you do.  You already know the verb 'trabajar' — this is the noun.

steps.origin: From Latin 'tripalium' — a wooden frame for holding animals still.
steps.story: It began as a word for effort and strain; now it means purpose and effort that builds life.
steps.wrap_line: ‘Trabajo’ is effort turned into meaning.

steps.line: Say: 'Tengo trabajo.' / 'El trabajo es bueno.'
Baby.
‘Bebé’ means baby — the smallest person, the start of life.  It can refer to boys or girls, so it works for everyone.

steps.origin: From French 'bébé,' itself from early baby sounds.
steps.story: Spanish borrowed the gentle sound because it feels natural to say.  It’s a word of care and tenderness.
steps.wrap_line: ‘Bebé’ is the sound of protection — soft, round, safe.

steps.line: Say: 'El bebé duerme.' / 'La bebé está feliz.'

steps.title: Familia / Habitación / Hermano / Idea / Esposa — Family, Room, Brother, Idea, Wife
steps.description: Five words that complete the home and thought circle — people, places, and imagination. Every sentence uses only verbs and adjectives already learned.

steps.line: Family.
‘Familia’ means family — the group of people who live or love together.  It can be big or small, near or far.

steps.origin: From Latin 'familia' — household.
steps.story: Spanish keeps the closeness of the word.  'Mi familia' is not only relatives; it’s everyone who feels like home.
steps.wrap_line: ‘Familia’ is belonging made simple.

steps.line: Say: 'Mi familia es grande.' / 'Estoy con mi familia.'
Room.
‘Habitación’ means room — a private space inside a house, hotel, or building.

steps.origin: From Latin 'habitare' — to live or dwell.
steps.story: It’s related to 'habitar' — to live somewhere.  Every 'habitación' is a little world with its own light.
steps.wrap_line: ‘Habitación’ is the word for space that belongs to you inside a home.

steps.line: Say: 'Estoy en mi habitación.' / 'La habitación es pequeña.'
Brother.
‘Hermano’ means brother; 'hermana' means sister.  It’s a family tie word full of warmth.

steps.origin: From Latin 'germanus' — of the same family.
steps.story: Spanish uses it for both blood and deep friendship: 'hermano' can mean literal or chosen brother.
steps.wrap_line: ‘Hermano’ is the sound of equality — someone who walks beside you.

steps.line: Say: 'Mi hermano trabaja.' / 'El hermano está en la casa.'
Idea.
‘Idea’ is the same in both languages — a thought, a plan, or a spark in the mind.

steps.origin: From Greek 'idea' — form, pattern, concept.
steps.story: Spanish kept it unchanged because ideas travel well.  It’s one of the easiest cognates in the language.
steps.wrap_line: ‘Idea’ is thought in motion.

steps.line: Say: 'Tengo una idea.' / 'La idea es buena.'
Wife.
‘Esposa’ means wife — the married partner.  It pairs with 'esposo' for husband.

steps.origin: From Latin 'sponsa' — promised one.
steps.story: In Spanish, it still carries that gentle promise inside it.  It’s the word for partnership, not possession.
steps.wrap_line: ‘Esposa’ is commitment written softly.

steps.line: Say: 'Mi esposa está en la casa.' / 'La esposa es amable.'
Wife.
‘Esposa’ means wife — the married partner.  It pairs with 'esposo' for husband.

steps.origin: From Latin 'sponsa' — promised one.
steps.story: In Spanish, it still carries that gentle promise inside it.  It’s the word for partnership, not possession.
steps.wrap_line: ‘Esposa’ is commitment written softly.

steps.line: Say: 'Mi esposa está en la casa.' / 'La esposa es buena.'

steps.title: Inicio / Puerta / Pedazo / Materia / Carrera — Start, Door, Piece, Material, Race
steps.description: Five story-based lessons about beginnings, openings, parts, things, and motion — all written with the verbs and adjectives already learned.

steps.line: Start. Beginning.
‘Inicio’ means start or beginning — the moment when something new starts moving.

steps.origin: From Latin 'initium' — beginning.
steps.story: Spanish keeps the image of first motion.  It’s used for life, projects, or even days: every morning is a small 'inicio.'
steps.wrap_line: ‘Inicio’ is the spark before movement.

steps.line: Say: 'Es el inicio del día.' / 'El inicio es bueno.'
Door.
‘Puerta’ means door — an opening between one place and another.

steps.origin: From Latin 'porta' — gate or entrance.
steps.story: Spanish uses it for both real and symbolic thresholds: home doors, new chances, or the day itself.
steps.wrap_line: ‘Puerta’ is the border between inside and out.

steps.line: Say: 'La puerta está abierta.' / 'Camino a la puerta.'
Piece. Bit.
‘Pedazo’ means a piece or part of something bigger — food, time, or an object.

steps.origin: From Old Spanish 'pedazo' — fragment.
steps.story: It’s a small, warm word used in daily life: 'un pedazo de pan' — a piece of bread.
steps.wrap_line: ‘Pedazo’ is the word for small but real things.

steps.line: Say: 'Quiero un pedazo de pan.' / 'El pedazo es pequeño.'
Matter. Material.
‘Materia’ means the substance something is made of — physical or abstract.  It can also mean a school subject.

steps.origin: From Latin 'materia' — wood, material, substance.
steps.story: Spanish kept its versatility: from science to poetry, 'materia' means the stuff of existence.
steps.wrap_line: ‘Materia’ is everything that fills space — thought or thing.

steps.line: Say: 'La materia es fuerte.' / 'Estudio la materia.'
Race. Career. Run.
‘Carrera’ means race or course — movement with purpose.  It’s used for running or for a life’s work.

steps.origin: From Latin 'carrus' — cart or wheel vehicle.
steps.story: In Spanish, motion becomes meaning: a 'carrera' can be a physical race or a career path — both journeys you build step by step.
steps.wrap_line: ‘Carrera’ is speed turned into life direction.

steps.line: Say: 'Tengo una carrera.' / 'La carrera es larga.'

steps.title: Escuela / Juego / Problema / Fin / Teléfono / Esperanza / Excusa / Cara / Turno / Policía — School to Police
steps.description: Ten short lessons continuing the A1 core vocabulary.  Each one stays inside known verbs and connectors and uses the familiar rhythm of meaning, story, and usage.

steps.line: School.
‘Escuela’ means school — the place where people learn together.

steps.origin: From Latin 'schola' — a place of learning.
steps.story: Spanish kept the simple, human meaning: a room, some voices, and new ideas.  It can be any place where learning happens.
steps.wrap_line: ‘Escuela’ is a house for knowledge.

steps.line: Say: 'Voy a la escuela.'  /  'La escuela es grande.'
Game. Play.
‘Juego’ means both a game and the act of playing.  It’s fun turned into motion.

steps.origin: From Latin 'jocus' — joke, play.
steps.story: It keeps joy inside it.  'Juego' reminds you that learning and playing share the same roots.
steps.wrap_line: ‘Juego’ is movement with laughter.

steps.line: Say: 'El juego es bueno.'  /  'Me gusta el juego.'
Problem.
‘Problema’ means problem — something to solve or fix.  The word sounds the same in both languages.

steps.origin: From Greek 'problema' — obstacle, question.
steps.story: Spanish uses it calmly; not every problem is bad — it’s just something waiting for attention.
steps.wrap_line: ‘Problema’ is a challenge, not a wall.

steps.line: Say: 'Tengo un problema.'  /  'El problema es pequeño.'
End.
‘Fin’ means the end or finish of something — a movie, a day, a path.

steps.origin: From Latin 'finis' — boundary, limit.
steps.story: Spanish also uses it in greetings and closure: 'al fin' — at last.  It’s not sad; it’s completion.
steps.wrap_line: ‘Fin’ is the quiet stop that gives meaning to motion.

steps.line: Say: 'Es el fin del día.'  /  'El fin es bueno.'
Phone.
‘Teléfono’ means phone — the tool for voice across distance.

steps.origin: From Greek roots 'tele' (far) + 'phono' (sound).
steps.story: Spanish kept the same root and sound.  It’s the word for contact without touch.
steps.wrap_line: ‘Teléfono’ is distance made smaller.

steps.line: Say: 'Tengo un teléfono.'  /  'El teléfono está en la mesa.'
Hope.
‘Esperanza’ means hope — belief in something good ahead.

steps.origin: From Latin 'sperare' — to hope or expect.
steps.story: Spanish turns the verb 'esperar' (to wait) into the noun 'esperanza' — showing that hope is patient waiting.
steps.wrap_line: ‘Esperanza’ is waiting with light inside.

steps.line: Say: 'Tengo esperanza.'  /  'La esperanza es buena.'
Excuse.
‘Excusa’ means excuse — a reason to explain a delay or mistake.  It can also be a polite word for forgiveness.

steps.origin: From Latin 'ex causa' — out of cause.
steps.story: Spanish kept its soft tone; 'una excusa' is not an argument, just a small reason.
steps.wrap_line: ‘Excusa’ is reason turned gentle.

steps.line: Say: 'Perdón, tengo una excusa.'  /  'La excusa es pequeña.'
Face.
‘Cara’ means face — what you show to the world.  It can also mean the front side of an object.

steps.origin: From Latin 'cara' — face, surface.
steps.story: Spanish uses it in both ways: the physical face and the visible side of things.  'Buena cara' means a good expression.
steps.wrap_line: ‘Cara’ is identity you can see.

steps.line: Say: 'La cara es bonita.'  /  'Tengo una cara feliz.'
Turn. Shift.
‘Turno’ means a turn or a shift — your time to act or work.

steps.origin: From Latin 'tornus' — circle, rotation.
steps.story: Spanish keeps the motion idea: every person or worker has a 'turno,' a moment in the circle.
steps.wrap_line: ‘Turno’ is order made fair.

steps.line: Say: 'Es mi turno.'  /  'El turno es corto.'
Police.
‘Policía’ means police or a police officer.  It can refer to the group or one person.

steps.origin: From Greek 'polis' — city.  Originally it meant order within a city.
steps.story: Spanish keeps that civic sense: the people who watch over public safety.
steps.wrap_line: ‘Policía’ is the guardian of calm.

steps.line: Say: 'La policía está en la calle.'  /  'La policía ayuda.'

steps.title: Corazón / Preocupación / Negocio / Reloj / Año / Mano / Médico / Segundo / Niño / Pago — Heart to Pay
steps.description: Ten A1-level lessons from heart to payment. Each one follows the familiar format: meaning, story, and simple usage.

steps.line: Heart.
‘Corazón’ means heart — the organ and the center of emotion.  Spanish uses it for body and love alike.

steps.origin: From Latin 'cor' — heart.
steps.story: It became the symbol of feeling in every romance language.  'Tienes buen corazón' means you’re kind.
steps.wrap_line: ‘Corazón’ is life and feeling beating together.

steps.line: Say: 'Tengo un corazón fuerte.' / 'El corazón es grande.'
Worry.
‘Preocupación’ means worry or concern — the mind working too much before something happens.

steps.origin: From Latin 'praeoccupare' — to occupy before.
steps.story: Spanish turned the idea of thinking ahead into a feeling.  A 'preocupación' is thought that can’t rest.
steps.wrap_line: ‘Preocupación’ is the mind walking in circles.

steps.line: Say: 'Tengo preocupación por mi familia.' / 'La preocupación es grande.'
Business.
‘Negocio’ means business or shop — any place or activity where people trade work for value.

steps.origin: From Latin 'negotium' — not leisure, occupation.
steps.story: Spanish kept the idea of movement and exchange.  A 'negocio' is effort that creates connection.
steps.wrap_line: ‘Negocio’ is the daily dance of trade.

steps.line: Say: 'El negocio está en la calle.' / 'Trabajo en un negocio pequeño.'
Watch. Clock.
‘Reloj’ means watch or clock — the object that counts time.

steps.origin: From Old French 'horloge' — timekeeper.
steps.story: Spanish reshaped the word into its own rhythm.  It’s masculine even with the final 'j'.
steps.wrap_line: ‘Reloj’ is the sound of seconds walking.

steps.line: Say: 'Tengo un reloj bonito.' / 'El reloj está en la mesa.'
Year.
‘Año’ marks the big circle of time — twelve months, one orbit around the sun.

steps.origin: From Latin 'annus' — year.
steps.story: Used for age, events, and seasons.  'Feliz año' is the New Year greeting.
steps.wrap_line: ‘Año’ is time measured in lives.

steps.line: Say: 'Es un año nuevo.' / 'Trabajo todo el año.'
Hand.
‘Mano’ means hand — your tool for touch and work.  It’s feminine even though it ends in 'o.'

steps.origin: From Latin 'manus' — hand.
steps.story: Spanish kept the gender change as an exception: 'la mano'.  The word carries both action and care.
steps.wrap_line: ‘Mano’ is strength with gentleness.

steps.line: Say: 'La mano está fría.' / 'Tengo una mano limpia.'
Doctor.
‘Médico’ means doctor — the person who helps heal.  It’s masculine by form, but 'médica' works for a woman.

steps.origin: From Latin 'medicus' — healer.
steps.story: Spanish kept the direct, human sense.  It’s a word of trust.
steps.wrap_line: ‘Médico’ is knowledge turned into care.

steps.line: Say: 'Voy al médico mañana.' / 'El médico está en el hospital.'
Second.
‘Segundo’ means a moment in time — one small step after another.  It also means 'second' in order.

steps.origin: From Latin 'secundus' — following.
steps.story: It literally means 'the next one.'  Spanish kept that sense of continuity and smallness.
steps.wrap_line: ‘Segundo’ is time too small to see but big enough to matter.

steps.line: Say: 'Un segundo, por favor.' / 'Cada segundo es tiempo.'
Child.
‘Niño’ is boy or child; 'niña' is girl or child.  You’ve met them before, but now they stand as full nouns.

steps.origin: From Latin 'ninus' — small one.
steps.story: They hold the meaning of youth and possibility — small life still growing.
steps.wrap_line: ‘Niño / niña’ are the words for beginnings in human form.

steps.line: Say: 'El niño camina.' / 'La niña está feliz.'
Payment.
‘Pago’ means payment — what you give for work or things.  It’s the noun from the verb 'pagar.'

steps.origin: From Latin 'pacare' — to satisfy or settle.
steps.story: It keeps a quiet fairness: work done, payment given.  The idea of balance lives in it.
steps.wrap_line: ‘Pago’ is the closing handshake of exchange.

steps.line: Say: 'Tengo un pago hoy.' / 'El pago es bueno.'

steps.title: Agua / Muerte / Cosas / Minuto / Parte / Persona / Bebida / Cambio / Golpe / Cheque — Water to Check
steps.description: Ten short lessons about essentials of life, time, and exchange — all written with familiar verbs and grammar only.

steps.line: Water.
‘Agua’ means water — life itself.  It’s feminine, but uses 'el' before it in speech for sound: 'el agua.'

steps.origin: From Latin 'aqua' — water.
steps.story: It’s one of the oldest words we still use.  Every person and place depends on it.
steps.wrap_line: ‘Agua’ is the word for life in motion.

steps.line: Say: 'Bebo agua.' / 'El agua es buena.'
Death.
‘Muerte’ means death — the natural end of life.  Spanish speaks of it calmly; it’s part of the same circle as 'vida.'

steps.origin: From Latin 'mors' → 'mortem' — death.
steps.story: The word is often gentle in Spanish, used with respect or poetry.
steps.wrap_line: ‘Muerte’ is the pause that lets life shine brighter.

steps.line: Say: 'La muerte es parte de la vida.'
Things.
‘Cosas’ means things — objects or matters when you don’t need to name them one by one.

steps.origin: From Latin 'causa' — cause, matter.
steps.story: It covers nearly everything — ideas, objects, issues.  A universal word.
steps.wrap_line: ‘Cosas’ is the basket that holds everything unnamed.

steps.line: Say: 'Tengo muchas cosas.' / 'Las cosas son pequeñas.'
Minute.
‘Minuto’ means minute — sixty small parts of an hour.

steps.origin: From Latin 'minutus' — small, divided.
steps.story: It’s the word that measures patience.  Each 'minuto' is a chance to breathe.
steps.wrap_line: ‘Minuto’ is small time with big use.

steps.line: Say: 'Un minuto, por favor.' / 'Cada minuto es tiempo.'
Part.
‘Parte’ means a piece or section of a whole.  It can describe space, time, or story.

steps.origin: From Latin 'partem' — share, division.
steps.story: You’ll hear it often in daily speech: 'una parte del día' — a part of the day.
steps.wrap_line: ‘Parte’ is the idea that everything belongs to something bigger.

steps.line: Say: 'Es una parte del trabajo.' / 'La parte es pequeña.'
Person.
‘Persona’ means person — one human being.  It’s neutral and kind.

steps.origin: From Latin 'persona' — mask or role.
steps.story: It originally meant an actor’s mask, then came to mean the person themselves.  Spanish kept the humanity.
steps.wrap_line: ‘Persona’ is the face and the heart together.

steps.line: Say: 'Soy una persona feliz.' / 'La persona es buena.'
Drink.
‘Bebida’ means drink — the noun from 'beber.'  Anything you drink is a 'bebida.'

steps.origin: From Latin 'bibere' — to drink.
steps.story: It’s everyday vocabulary used everywhere — water, coffee, juice — all are 'bebidas.'
steps.wrap_line: ‘Bebida’ is refreshment in one word.

steps.line: Say: 'Tengo una bebida.' / 'La bebida es fría.'
Change.
‘Cambio’ means change — both difference and small money returned.

steps.origin: From Latin 'cambiare' — to exchange.
steps.story: Spanish uses it for life shifts and store counters alike: 'El cambio' can mean coins or transformation.
steps.wrap_line: ‘Cambio’ is movement made visible.

steps.line: Say: 'Tengo cambio.' / 'El cambio es bueno.'
Hit.
‘Golpe’ means a hit or impact.  It can be physical or emotional — something that strikes.

steps.origin: From Old Spanish 'golpar' — to strike.
steps.story: You’ll hear it in daily talk: 'un golpe de suerte' — a stroke of luck.
steps.wrap_line: ‘Golpe’ is sudden contact, not always pain.

steps.line: Say: 'Escucho un golpe.' / 'El golpe es fuerte.'
Check.
‘Cheque’ means check — a written order for payment, or the act of checking something.

steps.origin: From English 'check,' adopted into Spanish banking.
steps.story: It’s one of the simplest borrowings, keeping both spelling and sound.
steps.wrap_line: ‘Cheque’ is trust written on paper.

steps.line: Say: 'Tengo un cheque.' / 'El cheque es pequeño.'

steps.title: Música / Interior / Sueño / Acuerdo / Punto / Cuerpo / Oportunidad / Fiesta / Hija / Palabra — Music to Word
steps.description: Ten story-based A1 lessons linking art, rest, agreement, and daily life.  Each card uses only known grammar and vocabulary.

steps.line: Music.
‘Música’ means music — organized sound that moves feeling.  Spanish uses it for songs and for the art itself.

steps.origin: From Greek 'mousike' — art of the Muses.
steps.story: It arrived in Spanish unchanged.  A universal word; everyone understands 'música'.
steps.wrap_line: ‘Música’ is emotion you can hear.

steps.line: Say: 'Me gusta la música.'  /  'La música es buena.'
Inside.
‘Interior’ means inside — the inner space of a room, object, or person.

steps.origin: From Latin 'interior' — inner.
steps.story: Spanish uses it for buildings and for emotions: 'mi interior' — my inner self.
steps.wrap_line: ‘Interior’ is the quiet space within.

steps.line: Say: 'Estoy en el interior de la casa.'  /  'El interior es grande.'
Sleep. Dream.
‘Sueño’ means both sleep and dream — rest and imagination share one word.

steps.origin: From Latin 'somnium' — dream.
steps.story: In Spanish, to say 'tengo sueño' is to say 'I’m sleepy.'  The word carries peace and vision together.
steps.wrap_line: ‘Sueño’ is rest with color.

steps.line: Say: 'Tengo sueño.'  /  'El sueño es bueno.'
Agreement.
‘Acuerdo’ means agreement — when people share one decision or understanding.

steps.origin: From Latin 'accordare' — to make hearts agree.
steps.story: The root 'cor' means heart; an 'acuerdo' is hearts in rhythm.  You can say 'estamos de acuerdo' — we agree.
steps.wrap_line: ‘Acuerdo’ is harmony between minds.

steps.line: Say: 'Tenemos un acuerdo.'  /  'El acuerdo es bueno.'
Point.
‘Punto’ means a point, spot, or idea of precision.  It marks ends and connections.

steps.origin: From Latin 'punctum' — mark made by a point.
steps.story: Spanish uses it in writing, space, and time: 'un punto' on paper or in argument.
steps.wrap_line: ‘Punto’ is focus made visible.

steps.line: Say: 'El punto es pequeño.'  /  'Este es el punto del día.'
Body.
‘Cuerpo’ means body — the physical part of a person or thing.

steps.origin: From Latin 'corpus' — body.
steps.story: Spanish sees body and mind as partners: 'el cuerpo y la mente.'
steps.wrap_line: ‘Cuerpo’ is the house of life.

steps.line: Say: 'El cuerpo es fuerte.'  /  'Tengo un cuerpo cansado.'
Chance. Opportunity.
‘Oportunidad’ means opportunity — the opening that appears at the right time.

steps.origin: From Latin 'opportunitas' — fitness, favorable moment.
steps.story: Spanish uses it for luck that meets action.  'Tengo una oportunidad' — I have a chance.
steps.wrap_line: ‘Oportunidad’ is the door when it opens.

steps.line: Say: 'Tengo una oportunidad.'  /  'La oportunidad es buena.'
Party. Celebration.
‘Fiesta’ means celebration — a gathering with food, music, and joy.

steps.origin: From Latin 'festum' — feast.
steps.story: In Spanish culture, every town has a 'fiesta.'  It’s not noise — it’s life shared.
steps.wrap_line: ‘Fiesta’ is joy with others.

steps.line: Say: 'La fiesta es grande.'  /  'Estoy en la fiesta.'
Daughter.
‘Hija’ means daughter — the feminine form of 'hijo.'

steps.origin: From Latin 'filia' — daughter.
steps.story: Spanish uses it the same way as English, with warmth and pride.
steps.wrap_line: ‘Hija’ is family in a single word.

steps.line: Say: 'Mi hija está en la escuela.'  /  'La hija es buena.'
Word.
‘Palabra’ means word — a single piece of language.  It’s what you build everything else from.

steps.origin: From Latin 'parabola' — speech, comparison.
steps.story: Spanish kept the sound but made it smaller and everyday.  Every sentence begins with a 'palabra.'
steps.wrap_line: ‘Palabra’ is thought you can hear.

steps.line: Say: 'Aprendo una palabra nueva.'  /  'La palabra es bonita.'

steps.title: Diversión / Número / Historia / Conjunto / Deseo / Esposo / Fuego / Pelea / Descanso / Momento / Semana / Juego / Hermana / Lado / Verdad — Fun to Truth
steps.description: The closing set of A1-level vocabulary lessons (86–100).  Each word is taught through meaning, story, and safe usage sentences built only from known Spanish.

steps.line: Fun.
‘Diversión’ means fun or amusement — the pleasure of doing something you enjoy.

steps.origin: From Latin 'divertere' — to turn aside.
steps.story: Originally it meant turning away from work for a while.  In Spanish it still feels like freedom.
steps.wrap_line: ‘Diversión’ is rest with laughter.

steps.line: Say: 'La fiesta es diversión.'  /  'Tengo mucha diversión con mis amigos.'
Number.
‘Número’ means number — a way to count or name order.

steps.origin: From Latin 'numerus' — number.
steps.story: It’s one of the easiest cognates.  Spanish uses it for counting, addresses, and phone numbers.
steps.wrap_line: ‘Número’ is order made visible.

steps.line: Say: 'Mi número es siete.'  /  'El número está en la puerta.'
Story. History.
‘Historia’ means both story and history — the telling of what happened.

steps.origin: From Greek 'historia' — inquiry, record.
steps.story: Spanish uses it for personal tales and world events alike.
steps.wrap_line: ‘Historia’ is memory in motion.

steps.line: Say: 'Tengo una historia.'  /  'La historia es buena.'
Set. Group.
‘Conjunto’ means group or set — things that go together.

steps.origin: From Latin 'coniunctus' — joined together.
steps.story: In Spanish, it can mean a music band or any collection united by purpose.
steps.wrap_line: ‘Conjunto’ is unity made visible.

steps.line: Say: 'El conjunto es grande.'  /  'Trabajo con un conjunto de personas.'
Wish. Desire.
‘Deseo’ means a wish or desire — something the heart wants.

steps.origin: From Latin 'desiderare' — to long for.
steps.story: Spanish keeps its softness: a 'deseo' can be romantic, simple, or spiritual.
steps.wrap_line: ‘Deseo’ is longing turned into language.

steps.line: Say: 'Tengo un deseo.'  /  'El deseo es fuerte.'
Husband.
‘Esposo’ means husband — the masculine partner, paired with 'esposa'.

steps.origin: From Latin 'sponsus' — promised man.
steps.story: Spanish kept the sense of partnership, never ownership.
steps.wrap_line: ‘Esposo’ is commitment with kindness.

steps.line: Say: 'Mi esposo trabaja.'  /  'El esposo está feliz.'
Fire.
‘Fuego’ means fire — both the physical flame and energy or passion.

steps.origin: From Latin 'focus' — hearth, flame.
steps.story: It’s the twin of 'hogar' — the fire that turns a place into a home.
steps.wrap_line: ‘Fuego’ is warmth and danger in one sound.

steps.line: Say: 'El fuego es grande.'  /  'Hay fuego en la casa.'
Fight.
‘Pelea’ means fight or argument — when people or ideas collide.

steps.origin: From Latin 'pila' — hit, strike.
steps.story: It can mean a real fight or a small discussion.  Context makes it soft or strong.
steps.wrap_line: ‘Pelea’ is noise that asks to become peace.

steps.line: Say: 'La pelea es pequeña.'  /  'No quiero pelea.'
Rest.
‘Descanso’ means rest — the pause between efforts.

steps.origin: From Latin 'dis' + 'quiescere' — to become still again.
steps.story: Spanish uses it for sleep, breaks, and even peace.  It’s the noun from 'descansar.'
steps.wrap_line: ‘Descanso’ is calm made visible.

steps.line: Say: 'Tengo un descanso.'  /  'El descanso es bueno.'
Moment.
‘Momento’ means moment — a short piece of time that matters.

steps.origin: From Latin 'momentum' — movement, impulse.
steps.story: A 'momento' can be fast or deep — one second that changes everything.
steps.wrap_line: ‘Momento’ is time with meaning.

steps.line: Say: 'Un momento, por favor.'  /  'Cada momento es vida.'
Week.
‘Semana’ means week — seven days of rhythm and routine.

steps.origin: From Latin 'septimana' — group of seven days.
steps.story: Spanish treats the week as one continuous block: 'toda la semana' — the whole week.
steps.wrap_line: ‘Semana’ is the shape of time at work.

steps.line: Say: 'Trabajo toda la semana.'  /  'La semana es larga.'
Game.
We met 'juego' before, but repetition helps.  It’s both the play and the spirit of play.

steps.origin: From Latin 'jocus' — play, joke.
steps.story: Same roots as joy and humor.  Spanish turns learning itself into a 'juego.'
steps.wrap_line: ‘Juego’ is learning with motion.

steps.line: Say: 'El juego es divertido.'  /  'Me gusta el juego.'
Sister.
‘Hermana’ means sister — the feminine form of 'hermano.'

steps.origin: From Latin 'germanus' — of the same family.
steps.story: Spanish uses it for real or chosen sisters — people of deep connection.
steps.wrap_line: ‘Hermana’ is family in the same rhythm.

steps.line: Say: 'Mi hermana está feliz.'  /  'La hermana es buena.'
Side.
‘Lado’ means side — position next to something.

steps.origin: From Latin 'latus' — side.
steps.story: Used in directions and emotion alike: 'a mi lado' — by my side.
steps.wrap_line: ‘Lado’ is closeness made physical.

steps.line: Say: 'La puerta está a mi lado.'  /  'Mi amigo está a mi lado.'
Truth.
‘Verdad’ means truth — what is real or honest.

steps.origin: From Latin 'veritas' — truth.
steps.story: In Spanish, 'la verdad' can also mean 'really' in talk: '¿La verdad?' — Really?  It’s both philosophy and daily honesty.
steps.wrap_line: ‘Verdad’ is honesty turned into sound.

steps.line: Say: 'La verdad es buena.'  /  'Digo la verdad.'

steps.title: Level 10B — A1 Vocabulary 101–150 (Lady → Voice)
steps.description: Fifty one-word lessons (201–250). Each card uses only previously installed verbs, connectors, and adjectives.

steps.line: Lady.
‘Dama’ is a formal word for woman, used with respect or elegance.

steps.origin: From Latin 'domina' — mistress, lady.
steps.story: Spanish keeps the polite tone; you hear it in greetings and events.
steps.wrap_line: ‘Dama’ is respect in one word.

steps.line: La dama está en la casa. / La dama es buena.
Shot.
‘Disparo’ is a single shot or firing; also used figuratively as a sudden event.

steps.origin: From 'disparar' — to fire.
steps.story: A short, sharp action; Spanish treats it as an event word.
steps.wrap_line: ‘Disparo’ is impact in one instant.

steps.line: Escucho un disparo. / El disparo es fuerte.
War.
‘Guerra’ means war — conflict between groups or countries.

steps.origin: From Gothic 'werra' — conflict.
steps.story: Spanish often pairs it with ‘paz’ to talk about contrast.
steps.wrap_line: ‘Guerra’ is the opposite of peace.

steps.line: La guerra es mala. / Quiero paz, no guerra.
Walk. Ride.
‘Paseo’ is an easy walk or ride — movement for pleasure.

steps.origin: From 'pasear' — to stroll.
steps.story: A word of calm motion; used for rest and small trips.
steps.wrap_line: ‘Paseo’ is gentle travel.

steps.line: Voy de paseo. / El paseo es corto.
Reason.
‘Razón’ is the cause or logic for something.

steps.origin: From Latin 'ratio' — reason.
steps.story: Also means “to be right”: tener razón.
steps.wrap_line: ‘Razón’ is the why behind action.

steps.line: Tengo razón. / Busco la razón.
City.
‘Ciudad’ is a big place with many people and streets.

steps.origin: From Latin 'civitas' — city.
steps.story: Spanish uses it for identity and origin too.
steps.wrap_line: ‘Ciudad’ is people in close motion.

steps.line: Vivo en una ciudad. / La ciudad es grande.
Town. People.
‘Pueblo’ is a small town; also “the people” as a community.

steps.origin: From Latin 'populus' — people.
steps.story: Warm word for community life.
steps.wrap_line: ‘Pueblo’ is a home of many.

steps.line: El pueblo es pequeño. / Amo a mi pueblo.
Trust.
‘Confianza’ is confidence and trust in someone or something.

steps.origin: From Latin 'fidere' — to trust.
steps.story: A quiet word; often paired with familia, amigo.
steps.wrap_line: ‘Confianza’ is safety between people.

steps.line: Tengo confianza en mi familia. / La confianza es buena.
Question.
‘Pregunta’ is the question itself — not the act of asking.

steps.origin: From 'preguntar' — to ask.
steps.story: Used in class, work, and street talk.
steps.wrap_line: ‘Pregunta’ opens a door.

steps.line: Tengo una pregunta. / La pregunta es fácil.
Office.
‘Oficina’ is a workplace room or building.

steps.origin: From Latin 'officium' — duty, service.
steps.story: Work + order + time.
steps.wrap_line: ‘Oficina’ is work in a room.

steps.line: Estoy en la oficina. / La oficina es pequeña.
Half.
‘Mitad’ is one of two equal parts.

steps.origin: From Latin 'medietas' — middle.
steps.story: A word for sharing fairly.
steps.wrap_line: ‘Mitad’ is balance by two.

steps.line: Quiero la mitad. / Es la mitad del día.
Welcome.
‘Bienvenida’ is a welcome — a greeting that invites in.

steps.origin: ‘Bien’ + ‘venida’: good + arrival.
steps.story: Used at doors, events, homes.
steps.wrap_line: ‘Bienvenida’ is a warm door.

steps.line: Bienvenida a la casa. / Damos la bienvenida.
Couple. Pair.
‘Pareja’ is two that go together; often romantic partners.

steps.origin: From 'par' — pair.
steps.story: Also used for team tasks.
steps.wrap_line: ‘Pareja’ is two in rhythm.

steps.line: Somos pareja. / La pareja camina.
Power.
As a noun, ‘poder’ is power or ability (not the verb to be able).

steps.origin: From Latin 'potere' — to be able.
steps.story: Noun of capacity or control.
steps.wrap_line: ‘Poder’ (noun) is strength to act.

steps.line: El poder no es la verdad. / El poder es grande.
Bed.
‘Cama’ is the place to rest and sleep.

steps.origin: From Latin 'cama' — bed.
steps.story: Every hogar has a cama.
steps.wrap_line: ‘Cama’ is rest made simple.

steps.line: Estoy en la cama. / La cama es grande.
Answer.
‘Respuesta’ is the reply to a pregunta.

steps.origin: From 'responder' — to answer.
steps.story: Completes the dialogue cycle.
steps.wrap_line: ‘Respuesta’ closes a question.

steps.line: Tengo una respuesta. / La respuesta es buena.
Gun.
‘Pistola’ names the object; use with care and context.

steps.origin: From Italian 'pistola'.
steps.story: A concrete word; Spanish treats it literally.
steps.wrap_line: ‘Pistola’ is an object word, not an idea.

steps.line: No quiero pistola. / La pistola no es juego.
Line.
‘Línea’ is a drawn or imagined line; also a queue or route.

steps.origin: From Latin 'linea' — linen thread, line.
steps.story: Used in maps, art, plans.
steps.wrap_line: ‘Línea’ is a path made thin.

steps.line: La línea es larga. / Sigo la línea.
Team.
‘Equipo’ is a group that works together.

steps.origin: Likely from Old French 'esquipe'.
steps.story: Used for sports and projects.
steps.wrap_line: ‘Equipo’ is many as one.

steps.line: Trabajo con un equipo. / El equipo es grande.
News.
‘Noticias’ are new reports or information.

steps.origin: From Latin 'notitia' — knowledge.
steps.story: Plural by nature in Spanish.
steps.wrap_line: ‘Noticias’ are stories arriving.

steps.line: Tengo noticias. / Las noticias son buenas.
Dog.
‘Perro’ is the animal and friend at home; ‘perra’ for a female.

steps.origin: Origin uncertain, medieval Spanish.
steps.story: Common in daily life and street talk.
steps.wrap_line: ‘Perro’ is loyalty with a tail.

steps.line: El perro está en la casa. / Mi perro es feliz.
Food.
‘Comida’ is food in general; also a midday meal in many places.

steps.origin: From 'comer' — to eat.
steps.story: Everyday word in home and market.
steps.wrap_line: ‘Comida’ is life’s fuel.

steps.line: La comida es buena. / Tengo comida.
Light.
‘Luz’ is light — from sun, lamp, or idea.

steps.origin: From Latin 'lux' — light.
steps.story: Used for both physics and hope.
steps.wrap_line: ‘Luz’ is what lets you see.

steps.line: La luz es bonita. / Tengo luz en la casa.
Country.
‘País’ is a nation — a big place with one name.

steps.origin: From French 'païs' — land.
steps.story: Used with ‘de’: soy de + país.
steps.wrap_line: ‘País’ is home at scale.

steps.line: Soy de un país grande. / Amo mi país.
Fact.
‘Hecho’ is a fact — something done or true.

steps.origin: From 'hacer' past participle — made/done.
steps.story: Noun form for reality in talk.
steps.wrap_line: ‘Hecho’ is truth made solid.

steps.line: Es un hecho. / Tengo un hecho claro.
Boss.
‘Jefe’ is the leader at work; ‘jefa’ for a woman.

steps.origin: From Arabic 'sháyḫ' via Spanish shift.
steps.story: Everyday workplace word.
steps.wrap_line: ‘Jefe/Jefa’ is work direction.

steps.line: Mi jefe está en la oficina. / La jefa es buena.
Dinner.
‘Cena’ is the evening meal.

steps.origin: From Latin 'coena'.
steps.story: Linked to hogar and familia.
steps.wrap_line: ‘Cena’ is food plus home.

steps.line: Tengo cena en la casa. / La cena es buena.
Plan.
‘Plan’ is an organized idea for action.

steps.origin: From French/English 'plan'.
steps.story: Very common in daily talk.
steps.wrap_line: ‘Plan’ is tomorrow drawn today.

steps.line: Tengo un plan. / El plan es simple.
Book.
‘Libro’ is a book — pages with text or images.

steps.origin: From Latin 'liber' — book.
steps.story: Source of historia and idea.
steps.wrap_line: ‘Libro’ is a portable world.

steps.line: Tengo un libro. / El libro es nuevo.
Hour.
‘Hora’ is clock time; used with ‘es/son’ to tell time.

steps.origin: From Latin 'hora'.
steps.story: Frames routine and work.
steps.wrap_line: ‘Hora’ is time held still.

steps.line: Es la hora. / Tengo una hora libre.
Uncle.
‘Tío’ is the brother of a parent; ‘tía’ for aunt.

steps.origin: From Latin 'tius'.
steps.story: Family map word.
steps.wrap_line: ‘Tío/Tía’ are family branches.

steps.line: Mi tío está en el pueblo. / La tía es feliz.
Safe. Sure.
‘Seguro’ as an adjective means safe or certain.

steps.origin: From Latin 'securus' — free from care.
steps.story: Everyday adjective for calm.
steps.wrap_line: ‘Seguro’ is safety in tone.

steps.line: Estoy seguro. / La casa es segura.
Touch.
‘Toque’ is a touch, tap, or small detail.

steps.origin: From 'tocar' — to touch.
steps.story: Used for physical and style notes.
steps.wrap_line: ‘Toque’ is a small signal.

steps.line: Un toque y abro la puerta. / Me gusta ese toque.
Company.
‘Empresa’ is a business organization.

steps.origin: From 'emprender' — to undertake.
steps.story: Work, plan, trade in one word.
steps.wrap_line: ‘Empresa’ is a house of work.

steps.line: Trabajo en una empresa. / La empresa es grande.
Past.
‘Pasado’ is the time behind us.

steps.origin: From 'pasar' — to pass.
steps.story: Used with ayer, antes.
steps.wrap_line: ‘Pasado’ is time already walked.

steps.line: Es pasado. / Hablo del pasado.
Sound.
‘Sonido’ is any sound you hear.

steps.origin: From 'sonar' — to sound.
steps.story: Partner word with música, voz.
steps.wrap_line: ‘Sonido’ is vibration with meaning.

steps.line: Escucho un sonido. / El sonido es fuerte.
Hair.
‘Pelo’ is hair on the head or body.

steps.origin: From Latin 'pilus' — hair.
steps.story: Common in daily description.
steps.wrap_line: ‘Pelo’ is soft identity.

steps.line: Mi pelo es largo. / Tengo poco pelo.
Driving.
‘Conducción’ is the act of driving (the activity).

steps.origin: From 'conducir' — to drive/lead.
steps.story: Noun for movement by vehicle.
steps.wrap_line: ‘Conducción’ is guided motion.

steps.line: La conducción es lenta hoy. / Voy en coche.
Luck.
‘Suerte’ is luck — good or bad turns of life.

steps.origin: From Latin 'sors' — lot, fate.
steps.story: Used in wishes: buena suerte.
steps.wrap_line: ‘Suerte’ is chance with a smile.

steps.line: Tengo suerte. / Buena suerte.
Top.
‘Cima’ is the highest point of something.

steps.origin: From Latin 'cyma' — top.
steps.story: Physical or metaphorical peak.
steps.wrap_line: ‘Cima’ is height with effort.

steps.line: Estoy en la cima. / La cima es alta.
Victory.
‘Victoria’ is a win — success after effort.

steps.origin: From Latin 'victoria'.
steps.story: Paired with carrera, juego.
steps.wrap_line: ‘Victoria’ is effort rewarded.

steps.line: Tengo una victoria. / La victoria es grande.
Control.
‘Control’ is supervision or self-control.

steps.origin: Loanword via French/English.
steps.story: Common in business and routine.
steps.wrap_line: ‘Control’ is order in action.

steps.line: Tengo control. / El control es bueno.
Air.
‘Aire’ is what we breathe; also mood or style.

steps.origin: From Latin 'aer'.
steps.story: Used in poetry and daily life.
steps.wrap_line: ‘Aire’ is invisible life.

steps.line: El aire es frío. / Quiero aire.
Dance.
‘Baile’ is dance as an event or act.

steps.origin: From 'bailar' — to dance.
steps.story: Often with música and fiesta.
steps.wrap_line: ‘Baile’ is joy in motion.

steps.line: Hay baile en la fiesta. / Me gusta el baile.
Sex.
‘Sexo’ is biological sex or the topic of sex.

steps.origin: From Latin 'sexus'.
steps.story: Neutral noun; context gives tone.
steps.wrap_line: ‘Sexo’ is a fact word.

steps.line: Hablamos del sexo como tema. / Es un dato del cuerpo.
Hospital.
‘Hospital’ is the place for medical care.

steps.origin: From Latin 'hospitale'.
steps.story: Common public word.
steps.wrap_line: ‘Hospital’ is care in a building.

steps.line: Voy al hospital. / El médico está en el hospital.
Street.
‘Calle’ is the public road in a town or city.

steps.origin: From Latin 'callis' — path.
steps.story: Paired with dirección and lugar.
steps.wrap_line: ‘Calle’ is the city’s path.

steps.line: Estoy en la calle. / Camino en la calle.
Lie.
‘Mentira’ is a false statement.

steps.origin: From Latin 'mentiri' — to lie.
steps.story: Opposite word to verdad.
steps.wrap_line: ‘Mentira’ is untrue sound.

steps.line: Es mentira. / No quiero mentira.
Dream.
‘Sueño’ is dream or sleepiness as a noun.

steps.origin: From Latin 'somnium'.
steps.story: We used it before; here as pure noun card.
steps.wrap_line: ‘Sueño’ is rest with images.

steps.line: Tengo sueño. / Mi sueño es claro.
Voice.
‘Voz’ is the human sound used to speak and sing.

steps.origin: From Latin 'vox' — voice.
steps.story: Partner word with palabra and música.
steps.wrap_line: ‘Voz’ is the body of language.

steps.line: Tu voz es bonita. / Escucho una voz.

steps.title: Level 2 — The Grammar Spine (No-Fear)
steps.description: Grammar-first level that explains parts of speech and syntax in friendly English, contrasts them with Spanish, and interleaves A2 vocabulary bursts until the player reaches ~1000 total words.

lessons.title: What Do We Talk About When We Talk?

steps.line: Talking is LEGO. We have word-bricks. We click them together to say life.

English has word jobs: thing-words (nouns), do-words (verbs), paint-words (adjectives), glue-words (prepositions/connectors). Spanish has the same jobs, but some bricks wear outfits (gender, number). No jump scares: we name the jobs first, then try clothes later.

Let’s meet our first kind of do-word — the regular -AR verb. It’s the action that ends with a little ‘-ar’ tail, like a puppy wagging its verb-ness: hablar (to talk), cantar (to sing), trabajar (to work).
In English we mostly change *who* does it by adding a helper word: I talk, you talk, he talks. Spanish glues that info onto the verb itself. The tail comes off, and a new ending moves in.

steps.origin: Rule pattern for regular -AR verbs:
steps.story:
Take the -ar off and add endings: 
- yo **-o** → hablo (I talk)
- tú **-as** → hablas (you talk)
- él/ella **-a** → habla (he/she talks)
- nosotros **-amos** → hablamos (we talk)
- vosotros **-áis** → habláis (you all talk — Spain)
- ellos/ellas **-an** → hablan (they talk)
It’s like a dance — the ending changes partners depending on who’s dancing.
steps.wrap_line: Spanish verbs don’t need a pronoun every time, because the ending already says who’s doing it.

When we talk, we point at stuff. We name it. That’s the start of grammar. Grammar is just how talking works — how all the words take turns so we can make sense. The first kind of word we ever make is the name-word — the noun — the word for a thing you can point at or imagine.

In Spanish, the word for 'noun' is **sustantivo** — something that *stands on its own.* Every sustantivo has two small tags stuck to it: gender (masculine or feminine) and number (one or many). These tags are not about people; they’re about pattern. They help the other words know what outfit to wear.

steps.origin: From Latin *substantivus* — 'that which has substance.' Spanish kept the habit of giving each noun an ending so other words could agree with it.
steps.story: Most nouns ending in **-o** are masculine, like **el libro** (the book). Most ending in **-a** are feminine, like **la casa** (the house). steps.title: How Talking Works — Pluralization (When There’s More Than One)

steps.line: Once you can name one thing, your brain immediately wants to count. One cat... two cats! That idea — more than one — is called **pluralization.** English shows it with a simple –s at the end: one book, two books.

Spanish does the same thing, but it cares a little more about sound. If a word ends in a vowel, you just add **–s**: *libro → libros*. If it ends in a consonant, you add **–es**: *flor → flores*. Spanish listens to the rhythm — it wants the plural to be easy to say out loud.

steps.origin: From Latin plural forms *–i* and *–es.* Over centuries, Spanish simplified them into two musical endings.
steps.story: Latin loved endings that made sound harmony across a sentence. Spanish kept the music but dropped the heavy rules. The idea stayed simple: if it feels open (ends in a vowel), whisper an *s*; if it feels closed (ends in a consonant), open it back up with *–es.* It’s not math — it’s melody.
steps.wrap_line: So when you say *libros* or *flores*, you’re following the same beat that Romans did two thousand years ago, just in modern clothes.

steps.title: How Talking Works — Articles & Gender (The Outfit Rule)

steps.line: Every noun likes to travel with a helper — a small word that points to it. In English, that helper is 'the' or 'a.' In Spanish, these helpers are called **articles**, and they change shape to match the noun they’re talking about. Think of them like little jackets that have to fit.

There are four main jackets:
• **el** — the (masculine, one)
• **la** — the (feminine, one)
• **los** — the (masculine, many)
• **las** — the (feminine, many)
If you want 'a' or 'an,' you use **un** or **una.**
Everything must agree: if the noun is feminine and plural, its jacket must be feminine and plural too.

steps.origin: From Latin articles and endings: *illum, illa, illos, illas.* Over time, Spanish smoothed them into el, la, los, las.
steps.story: Back in Latin, words had endings that showed exactly how they fit into a sentence. Spanish kept those endings but turned them into their own little words. The result feels almost human: every noun walks into the room already wearing its outfit. *El libro* wears the masculine jacket. *La casa* wears the feminine one. They don’t fight — they just match.
steps.wrap_line: So when you say *el libro* or *la casa*, you’re showing the world you know how the words want to be seen — properly dressed for grammar.

steps.line: If nouns are the walls, adjectives are the paint. They describe color, size, feeling. In English, paint sticks the same way: big house, big houses. In Spanish, paint changes to match its wall.

steps.line: Questions are the heartbeat of language. In English, they start with who, what, where, when, why, how. Spanish has the same curious crew.

lessons.title: How Talking Works — Present Tense (The Everyday Time)

steps.line: The present tense is home base. It’s what’s happening right now — I eat, you live, we talk. Spanish marks it right on the verb’s ending.

–AR verbs: hablar → hablo, hablas, habla, hablamos, hablan.
–ER verbs: comer → como, comes, come, comemos, comen.
–IR verbs: vivir → vivo, vives, vive, vivimos, viven.

steps.line: Sometimes the action comes back to you. I wash myself. You wake yourself up. In Spanish these are called reflexive verbs — the action bounces off the mirror.

steps.line: Every language has its dance steps. English likes a steady beat: subject + verb + object — I eat apples. Spanish knows the same dance but can spin a little.

lessons.title: How Talking Works — Past Tense (The Story That Finished)

steps.line: The past tense is how we tell stories that already happened. In English we add -ed or change the word: I worked, I went. Spanish tells time by changing the ending of the verb.

lessons.title: How Talking Works — Modal Verbs (Can, Should, Must, Want)

steps.line: Sometimes we don’t just act — we judge the action. Can we? Should we? Must we? Modal verbs express permission and desire.
poder — can; deber — should; tener que — must; querer — want. They always lead into another verb: puedo hablar, debo trabajar, tengo que estudiar, quiero comer.

steps.origin: From Latin verbs potere, debere, tenere, quaerere.
steps.story: Modals show mood, not motion. They’re how grammar whispers feelings: hope, duty, wish, power.
steps.wrap_line: Modal verbs are grammar’s conscience — tiny hearts before the verb.

steps.line:
Practice:
• puedo trabajar (I can work)
• debo estudiar (I should study)
• quiero descansar (I want to rest)

lessons.title: How Talking Works — Simple Prepositions (Little Bridges)

steps.line: Prepositions are small bridges that tell where, when, and how things connect. They’re the quiet engineers of language.
a — to; de — from/of; en — in/on; con — with; por — through/for; para — for/purpose. Each builds a bridge between ideas.

steps.origin: From Latin pre-ponere — 'placed before.'
steps.story: Old Latin engineers loved tidy structure. Spanish kept the same tiny stones, each one still leading somewhere.
steps.wrap_line: Prepositions are the walkways between your words.

steps.line:
Practice:
• en casa (at home)
• con mi amigo (with my friend)
• para ti (for you)

lessons.title: How Talking Works — Question Practice (Mini Interviews)

steps.line: Let’s practice curiosity — the grammar of conversation. Questions open doors; answers close them kindly.
Use question words you know: qué, quién, cuándo, dónde, por qué, cómo. Keep tone rising at the end; Spanish doesn’t need helper verbs like 'do.'

steps.origin: From the Latin habit of front-loading question words.
steps.story: Even Romans tilted their voice at the end of a question. Some habits never die.
steps.wrap_line: Asking is learning — grammar with heartbeat.

steps.line:
Practice:
• ¿Qué haces? (What do you do?)
• ¿Dónde trabajas? (Where do you work?)
• ¿Cómo estás? (How are you?)

lessons.title: How Talking Works — Comparatives Part 2 (Opinion and Feeling)

steps.line: Comparatives can also carry emotion. They’re how we weigh what we like more or less.
Use me gusta más... or menos... Example: me gusta más el café que el té.

steps.origin: From Latin plus/minus gustare — 'to taste more/less.'
steps.story: Romans used comparison to debate taste and art. Spanish does it to share preference, not argue.
steps.wrap_line: Comparatives in feeling are kindness with math — gentle judgment.

steps.line:
Practice:
• me gusta más el café que el té
• me gusta menos el frío
• me gusta la música más que el silencio

lessons.title: How Talking Works — Word Order Part 2 (Keeping the Beat)

steps.line: Word order gives sentences their beat. Once you know the rhythm, you can play with it like music.
Keep the basic beat: subject + verb + object. Move words only when you want focus: Hoy estudio español (Today I study Spanish) → Estudio español hoy (I study Spanish today).

steps.origin: From Latin’s free movement of words for poetry and emphasis.
steps.story: Spanish inherited the freedom but sets a comfortable rhythm for clarity. Moving a word is like moving a drumbeat — it changes the feeling.
steps.wrap_line: Word order is the groove of grammar — steady, flexible, alive.

steps.line:
Practice:
• Yo estudio español hoy
• Hoy estudio español
• Español estudio hoy (only for style)

lessons.title: How Talking Works — Connectors (The Glue of Thought)

steps.line: When ideas meet, they need glue. Connectors hold thoughts together so they don’t fall apart mid-sentence.
Common Spanish connectors: y (and), pero (but), porque (because), entonces (then), también (also), aunque (although).

steps.origin: From Latin conjunctions et, per hoc, quia, tamen.
steps.story: Romans built roads; they also built word-roads. Spanish still drives on them every day.
steps.wrap_line: Connectors are grammar’s traffic lights — they keep meaning moving safely.

steps.line:
Practice:
• Trabajo y estudio.
• Estoy cansado pero feliz.
• Leo porque me gusta.

lessons.title: How Talking Works — Time Markers (The When Words)

steps.line: Time words are the anchors of stories — they tell when something happens.
Key markers: hoy (today), ayer (yesterday), mañana (tomorrow), siempre (always), nunca (never), a veces (sometimes).

steps.origin: From Latin hodie, heri, mane, semper, numquam.
steps.story: These small words let a story stretch across hours and lives. Spanish puts them before or after the verb for rhythm.
steps.wrap_line: Time markers are grammar’s clocks — tick-tock words.

steps.line:
Practice:
• Trabajo hoy.
• Estudio mañana.
• Nunca como carne.

lessons.title: How Talking Works — Negation (The Little No)

steps.line: Sometimes meaning flips with one small word: no. English adds not; Spanish just puts no before the verb.
Formula: no + verb. Example: no trabajo (I don’t work), no tengo (I don’t have).

steps.origin: From Latin non — pure negation, short and strong.
steps.story: Spanish kept it simple. No is a wall built from one brick.
steps.wrap_line: Negation is power in one syllable — the gentlest stop sign.

steps.line:
Practice:
• No hablo inglés.
• No quiero café.
• No hay problema.

lessons.title: How Talking Works — Adverbs of Manner (The How-Words)

steps.line: Adverbs tell how something happens: slowly, well, badly. They’re the mood lighting of verbs.
Many Spanish adverbs end in -mente: rápidamente (quickly), fácilmente (easily). Some stay short: bien (well), mal (badly).

steps.origin: -mente comes from Latin mente — ‘with mind.’
steps.story: To do something rápidamente is literally to do it ‘with a quick mind.’
steps.wrap_line: Adverbs are thoughts hitching a ride on action.

steps.line:
Practice:
• Hablo bien.
• Trabajo rápidamente.
• Canta mal hoy.

lessons.title: How Talking Works — Frequency (The Habit Clock)

steps.line: Frequency words show how often something happens. They’re grammar’s calendar habits.
siempre (always), a menudo (often), a veces (sometimes), rara vez (rarely), nunca (never). Usually before or after the verb.

steps.origin: From Latin ad frequentiam — ‘crowding, repetition.’
steps.story: They remind us that life repeats, and so does grammar.
steps.wrap_line: Frequency words turn single actions into patterns.

steps.line:
Practice:
• Siempre estudio.
• A veces leo.
• Nunca duermo temprano.

lessons.title: How Talking Works — Emotion Words (Feeling on the Page)

steps.line: Emotions color sentences. Happy, sad, tired — adjectives that live close to estar because feelings change.
Use estar + emotion: estoy feliz, estás cansado, ella está triste.

steps.origin: From Latin stare — ‘to stand,’ later ‘to be in a state.’
steps.story: Estar shows temporary states — like weather in your heart.
steps.wrap_line: Emotion words teach verbs empathy.

steps.line:
Practice:
• Estoy feliz.
• Ella está cansada.
• Estamos bien.

lessons.title: How Talking Works — Sequences (The Order of Events)

steps.line: Stories need steps: first, then, later. Sequence words keep the plot walking.
primero (first), después (after), luego (then), al final (at the end).

steps.origin: From Latin primum, de ex post, loco deinde, finalis.
steps.story: Romans were obsessed with order — their language marched in lines. Spanish still walks to that beat.
steps.wrap_line: Sequence is grammar’s timeline — footprints in meaning.

steps.line:
Practice:
• Primero desayuno, luego trabajo.
• Después descanso.
• Al final duermo.

lessons.title: How Talking Works — Story Frames (The Mini Narrative)

steps.line: A story frame holds a beginning, middle, and end even in three lines.
Start (ayer / hoy), action (verb in present or past), feeling (al final estoy feliz / cansado).

steps.origin: From Latin narrare — ‘to tell.’
steps.story: Language evolved as shared memory; grammar is just the recipe for it.
steps.wrap_line: Story frames are micro-time machines.

steps.line:
Practice:
• Hoy trabajo, luego descanso, al final estoy feliz.

lessons.title: How Talking Works — Connective Phrases (The Stitch Words)

steps.line: Connective phrases are little bridges longer than one word: por eso, de hecho, al mismo tiempo.
por eso (therefore), de hecho (in fact), al mismo tiempo (at the same time).

steps.origin: From Latin prepositional stacks; Spanish glued them gently.
steps.story: Each phrase is a short hallway between ideas — step through and the topic changes without breaking.
steps.wrap_line: Connective phrases are the seamstress of stories.

steps.line:
Practice:
• Trabajo mucho, por eso descanso.
• Es bonito; de hecho, me gusta.

lessons.title: How Talking Works — Sentence Flow (The Breath of Speech)

steps.line: Sentences breathe. Too short — they gasp. Too long — they run out of air. Flow is how grammar inhales and exhales.
Spanish balances comma pauses with connectors: y, pero, porque. Short verbs keep the pulse steady.

steps.origin: From Latin periodus — ‘a run or course.’
steps.story: Roman rhetoric trained students to read sentences with breath. Spanish kept that human meter.
steps.wrap_line: Sentence flow is the breathing technique of speech.

steps.line:
Practice:
• Trabajo y descanso.
• Leo, pero no mucho.
• Hablo porque me gusta.

lessons.title: How Talking Works — Adverbs of Place (Where Things Happen)

steps.line: If verbs tell what happens, adverbs of place tell where it happens. They’re tiny maps in a word.
aquí (here), allí (there), cerca (near), lejos (far), dentro (inside), fuera (outside).

steps.origin: From Latin ad + verbum — 'to the word'; these specific ones come from locational roots meaning near/far/inside.
steps.story: Romans loved direction. Spanish kept their compass, turning full sentences into one-word coordinates.
steps.wrap_line: Adverbs of place are pocket-sized maps.

steps.line:
Practice:
• Estoy aquí.
• El libro está allí.
• El gato duerme dentro.

lessons.title: How Talking Works — Time Expressions (When the Day Moves)

steps.line: Some words measure time without clocks. Morning, afternoon, night — grammar’s daylight markers.
por la mañana (in the morning), por la tarde (in the afternoon), por la noche (at night), a las ocho (at eight).

steps.origin: From Latin hora and tempus — hour and time.
steps.story: Latin loved naming every light change. Spanish inherited the poetry of the sun’s schedule.
steps.wrap_line: Time expressions paint grammar with sky color.

steps.line:
Practice:
• Trabajo por la mañana.
• Estudio por la noche.
• Como a las dos.

lessons.title: How Talking Works — Possession (Who Owns What)

steps.line: Ownership words are small flags: my, your, his, her. Spanish waves them too, but they match the noun they guard.
mi/mis (my), tu/tus (your), su/sus (his/her/their), nuestro/a/os/as (our). Example: mi casa, tus libros, nuestra amiga.

steps.origin: From Latin meus, tuus, suus — the first possessives in Europe’s grammar family.
steps.story: They survived because humans keep liking to say 'mine' softly.
steps.wrap_line: Possessives are grammar’s tiny hugs — holding things close.

steps.line:
Practice:
• Mi casa es grande.
• Tus libros están aquí.
• Nuestra amiga canta.

lessons.title: How Talking Works — Infinitives (The Bare Verbs)

steps.line: Before verbs get dressed with endings, they live naked and pure. That state is called the infinitive — the 'to do' form.
hablar (to speak), comer (to eat), vivir (to live). Spanish infinitives end in -ar, -er, -ir.

steps.origin: From Latin infinitivus — 'without limit.'
steps.story: In Latin, infinitives were verbs without time or person — just potential energy. Spanish kept that timeless spark.
steps.wrap_line: Infinitives are verbs dreaming before they wake.

steps.line:
Practice:
• Quiero hablar.
• Necesito comer.
• Voy a vivir aquí.

lessons.title: How Talking Works — Compound Sentences (When Ideas Hold Hands)

steps.line: Sometimes one sentence isn’t enough. When two ideas connect with a word like 'and' or 'but,' you’ve made a compound sentence.
Use connectors: y (and), pero (but), porque (because), o (or). Each one joins equals.

steps.origin: From Latin cum + ponere — 'to place together.'
steps.story: The Romans loved symmetry; compound sentences were their linguistic architecture.
steps.wrap_line: Compound sentences are two thoughts holding hands politely.

steps.line:
Practice:
• Trabajo y estudio.
• Leo pero no escribo.
• Escucho música porque me gusta.

lessons.title: How Talking Works — Opposites (Light and Shadow)

steps.line: Languages love contrast. Hot–cold, big–small, happy–sad. Opposites make meaning visible by comparison.
Use adjectives with es/está: el día es largo, la noche es corta. Add no to flip: no es largo → es corto.

steps.origin: From Latin contrarius — 'turned against.'
steps.story: Old Latin philosophers taught through opposites; Spanish inherited that balance trick.
steps.wrap_line: Opposites are grammar’s flashlight — they define shape by shadow.

steps.line:
Practice:
• El café está frío, el té está caliente.
• La casa es grande, el libro es pequeño.

lessons.title: How Talking Works — Numbers (Counting the World)

steps.line: Counting is the grammar of order. One, two, three — each number is a little piece of math that turns into language.
uno, dos, tres, cuatro, cinco... diez. Spanish numbers change slightly for gender when used as adjectives: un libro / una casa.

steps.origin: From Latin unus, duo, tres — ancient counting stones.
steps.story: Numbers were humanity’s first grammar — proof we could measure and remember.
steps.wrap_line: Numbers are words with rulers attached.

steps.line:
Practice:
• Tengo un libro.
• Hay tres casas.
• Dos amigos estudian.

lessons.title: How Talking Works — Positional Phrases (Where Exactly)

steps.line: When 'where' needs more detail, we use phrases like in front of, behind, next to. Spanish has its own map set.
delante de (in front of), detrás de (behind), al lado de (next to), entre (between), sobre (on top of).

steps.origin: From Latin de + locative roots meaning 'position or place.'
steps.story: Roman soldiers gave exact orders; these words were the coordinates of empire. Spanish still uses them to find the salt at dinner.
steps.wrap_line: Positional phrases are grammar’s GPS — simple, precise, polite.

steps.line:
Practice:
• El gato está detrás de la silla.
• El libro está sobre la mesa.

lessons.title: How Talking Works — Contractions (The Word Shortcuts)

steps.line: When words travel together a lot, they start sharing luggage. That’s a contraction — two words squeezed into one.
Spanish has two: a + el = al, de + el = del. Example: voy al parque, el libro del profesor.

steps.origin: From Latin ad illum and de illum compacted in speech.
steps.story: Even Romans got lazy when talking fast; Spanish just made it official.
steps.wrap_line: Contractions are grammar’s carpool — shorter ride, same meaning.

steps.line:
Practice:
• Voy al mercado.
• El perro del amigo.

lessons.title: How Talking Works — Summary Patterns (The Review Grid)

steps.line: Every few lessons, grammar needs a mirror to admire itself. Summary patterns show how the pieces connect.
Combine noun + adjective + verb + connector: La casa es grande y bonita; El amigo trabaja y canta.

steps.origin: Pattern drills descend from Latin grammar schools.
steps.story: Teachers once wrote full grids of endings on wax tablets. Today we speak them instead.
steps.wrap_line: Summary patterns are grammar’s selfie — a picture of everything learned so far.

steps.line:
Practice:
• El día es largo y bueno.
• La casa es grande y bonita.
