lessons.title: How Talking Works — Story Links (Threading Ideas)

steps.line: Stories are strings of thoughts.  To make them hold, we use little knots called transitions.
Spanish favorites: después (after), luego (then), mientras (while), cuando (when).

steps.origin: From Latin trans + ire — 'to go across.'
steps.story: These tiny bridges carry readers from one moment to the next.
steps.wrap_line: Transitions are grammar’s thread through time.

steps.line:
Practice:
• Leo y luego escribo.
• Como mientras escucho música.

lessons.title: How Talking Works — Reason Phrases (Because Grammar)

steps.line: Every action has a why.  Reason phrases glue cause to effect.
porque (because), ya que (since), como (as).  Example: estudio porque quiero aprender.

steps.origin: From Latin per quod — 'by which.'
steps.story: Romans couldn’t stop explaining themselves.  Spanish inherited their love of logic.
steps.wrap_line: Reason phrases are grammar’s why-bubbles.

steps.line:
Practice:
• Trabajo porque necesito dinero.
• Leo ya que me gusta.

lessons.title: How Talking Works — Weather & Temperature (Small Talk Sky)

steps.line: Weather words are survival grammar—what we all talk about first.
Hace frío (it’s cold), hace calor (it’s hot), llueve (it rains), nieva (it snows).

steps.origin: From Latin facere — 'to make'— so literally 'it makes cold.'
steps.story: Spanish treats weather like an artist at work.  The sky is busy making moods.
steps.wrap_line: Weather verbs are grammar’s small talk with the universe.

steps.line:
Practice:
• Hace sol hoy.
• Llueve mucho.

lessons.title: How Talking Works — Directional Verbs (Motion Lines)

steps.line: Movement verbs are lines on the map of speech: go, come, leave, arrive.
ir (to go) → voy, vas, va, vamos, van; venir (to come) → vengo, vienes, viene, venimos, vienen; salir (to leave), llegar (to arrive).

steps.origin: From Latin ire, venire, salire, ligare.
steps.story: Every language moves; Spanish just makes the travel sound like music.
steps.wrap_line: Directional verbs are grammar’s arrows in motion.

steps.line:
Practice:
• Voy a casa.
• Ella viene aquí.
• Llegamos temprano.

lessons.title: How Talking Works — Question Pairs (Ask & Answer)

steps.line: Questions and answers are mirror pairs.  Grammar trains them to face each other.
¿Dónde…? → En…; ¿Cuándo…? → A las…; ¿Qué…? → Es…; ¿Quién…? → Es….

steps.origin: Dialogue structure comes straight from classroom Latin drills.
steps.story: Teachers used to make students answer in rhythm.  Spanish kept the swing.
steps.wrap_line: Question pairs are grammar’s call-and-response choir.

steps.line:
Practice:
• ¿Dónde estás? — En casa.
• ¿Qué haces? — Trabajo.

lessons.title: How Talking Works — Preference Structures (What We Like)

steps.line: Talking about likes and dislikes is social grammar—it builds friends fast.
Use gustar with nouns: me gusta el café / no me gusta el frío.  For plural: me gustan las casas.

steps.origin: From Latin gustare — 'to taste.'
steps.story: Romans measured taste before time; Spanish still measures joy that way.
steps.wrap_line: Preference grammar is language tasting itself.

steps.line:
Practice:
• Me gusta el sol.
• No me gustan los lunes.

lessons.title: How Talking Works — Frequency Questions (How Often)

steps.line: Once you know habit words, you can ask about them: How often?
¿Con qué frecuencia…? (how often), ¿Cada cuánto…? (every how much). Use with frequency adverbs: siempre, nunca, a veces.

steps.origin: From Latin frequentia — 'crowd, repetition.'
steps.story: Ancient teachers noticed that repetition made language stick; Spanish made it conversation.
steps.wrap_line: Frequency questions are grammar’s rhythm check.

steps.line:
Practice:
• ¿Cada cuánto estudias? — Todos los días.
• ¿Con qué frecuencia lees? — A veces.

lessons.title: How Talking Works — Color Words (Painting the Noun)

steps.line: Colors make sentences visible.  They’re adjectives with a palette.
rojo (red), azul (blue), verde (green), negro (black), blanco (white). They match the noun’s gender and number: la casa blanca / los libros rojos.

steps.origin: From Latin color, caeruleus, viridis, niger, albus.
steps.story: Roman artists named pigments for minerals; grammar borrowed their art supplies.
steps.wrap_line: Color words prove that grammar has eyes.

steps.line:
Practice:
• El libro rojo.
• La casa blanca.
• Las flores verdes.

lessons.title: How Talking Works — Quantity Words (How Much / How Many)

steps.line: Quantity words measure reality.  They turn objects into amounts.
mucho/a/os/as (much, many), poco/a/os/as (few, little), todo/a/os/as (all), nada (nothing).  They agree with the noun.

steps.origin: From Latin multus, paucus, totus, nata.
steps.story: Numbers count; quantity words feel.  They were poetry first, math later.
steps.wrap_line: Quantity grammar is counting with emotion.

steps.line:
Practice:
• Tengo muchos libros.
• Hay poca agua.
• Quiero todo.

lessons.title: How Talking Works — Recap Patterns (Tying the Threads)

steps.line: Every now and then, grammar needs a knot to keep what we’ve learned from unraveling.
Mix: subject + verb + color + quantity + place + connector.  Example: El libro rojo está en la mesa y me gusta mucho.

steps.origin: From the medieval habit of 'recapitulatio' — retelling to remember.
steps.story: Old monks chanted summaries aloud; it worked.  Spanish learners can do the same.
steps.wrap_line: Recap patterns are grammar’s stitches — closing one design before the next.

steps.line:
Practice:
• La casa grande está lejos y tiene muchas flores.

lessons.title: How Talking Works — Time-of-Day Phrases (Morning to Night)

steps.line: Time tells stories in sunlight and moonlight.  These short phrases paint the hours.
por la mañana — in the morning; por la tarde — in the afternoon; por la noche — at night; de día / de noche — by day / by night.

steps.origin: From Latin 'tempus diei' — the time of day.
steps.story: Old Romans counted daylight by tasks: work, meal, prayer, rest. Spanish kept their rhythm.
steps.wrap_line: Time-of-day phrases are grammar’s daily heartbeat.

steps.line:
Practice:
• Trabajo por la mañana.
• Estudio por la noche.
• Descanso por la tarde.

lessons.title: How Talking Works — Food Words (Edible Grammar)

steps.line: Food is language you can taste. Meals build culture and vocabulary at once.
comida (food/meal), desayuno (breakfast), almuerzo (lunch), cena (dinner), agua (water), pan (bread).

steps.origin: From Latin 'comedere' — to eat up.
steps.story: Romans made 'comedere' a habit; Spanish turned it into daily comfort words.
steps.wrap_line: Food words are grammar that feeds you.

steps.line:
Practice:
• Como pan.
• Bebo agua.
• La comida es buena.

lessons.title: How Talking Works — SER vs ESTAR for Feelings (The Two Faces of 'To Be')

steps.line: English has one 'to be.' Spanish has two because existence can be permanent or temporary.
Use ser for identity: Soy mexicano. Use estar for state: Estoy feliz. Ser = what you are; estar = how you feel.

steps.origin: From Latin essere and stare — to exist and to stand.
steps.story: Romans separated being from standing; Spanish still feels the difference.
steps.wrap_line: Ser is the root; estar is the bloom.

steps.line:
Practice:
• Soy alto.
• Estoy cansado.
• Ella es mi amiga.

lessons.title: How Talking Works — Transport Words (Moving Grammar)

steps.line: Travel verbs carry you through space; vehicles carry nouns through sentences.
en coche (in a car), en bus (by bus), a pie (on foot), en tren (by train). Use ir + en + transport.

steps.origin: From Latin trans — across + portare — to carry.
steps.story: Moving meant carrying; grammar turned it into journey words.
steps.wrap_line: Transport words are grammar’s wheels.

steps.line:
Practice:
• Voy en bus.
• Camino a pie.
• Ella va en coche.

lessons.title: How Talking Works — HAY (There Is / There Are)

steps.line: To exist is to appear. Spanish uses one magic word for 'there is/are' — hay (pronounced like 'eye').
Formula: hay + noun → hay una casa (there is a house), hay libros (there are books). No change for plural.

steps.origin: From haber — to have/exist.
steps.story: Latin had 'habet' — 'it has.' Spanish softened it into existence itself.
steps.wrap_line: Hay is grammar’s light switch: on = there is.

steps.line:
Practice:
• Hay pan.
• Hay dos libros.
• No hay agua.

lessons.title: How Talking Works — Preference Comparisons (Likes in Balance)

steps.line: When two things compete for your heart, Spanish has a way to compare likes.
me gusta más ... que ... → I like ... more than ...; me gusta menos ... que ... → I like ... less than ...

steps.origin: From Latin magis and minus — more and less.
steps.story: The ancient math of pleasure: Romans weighed joy; Spanish still does.
steps.wrap_line: Preference comparisons are grammar’s taste test.

steps.line:
Practice:
• Me gusta más el café que el té.
• Me gusta menos el frío.

lessons.title: How Talking Works — Impersonal Expressions (The Neutral Voice)

steps.line: Sometimes nobody does the action. Things just happen. That’s impersonal grammar.
Use se + verb in 3rd person: se habla español — Spanish is spoken. It works like 'people say...' in English.

steps.origin: From Latin 'sibi' reflexive turned general.
steps.story: Romans used 'one says' for rules and proverbs; Spanish kept the humility.
steps.wrap_line: Impersonal expressions are grammar’s way of being polite and vague.

steps.line:
Practice:
• Se habla inglés aquí.
• Se vende pan.

lessons.title: How Talking Works — Questions About Quantity (How Much, How Many)

steps.line: Curiosity likes numbers. We ask 'how many' to see the size of the world.
¿Cuánto/a/os/as + noun? Example: ¿Cuántos libros hay? How many books are there? ¿Cuánta agua hay? How much water is there?

steps.origin: From Latin quantus — how great, how much.
steps.story: The word 'quantity' was born from it. Spanish kept the wonder in its sound.
steps.wrap_line: Quantity questions are grammar’s measuring cups.

steps.line:
Practice:
• ¿Cuántos amigos tienes?
• ¿Cuánta leche hay?

lessons.title: How Talking Works — Ordinal Numbers (The Order Words)

steps.line: Counting tells how many; ordinals tell which one comes where.
primero (first), segundo (second), tercero (third), cuarto (fourth), quinto (fifth). Used like adjectives.

steps.origin: From Latin primus, secundus, tertius — old ranking words.
steps.story: Romans loved lists almost as much as conquests; Spanish kept their order habit.
steps.wrap_line: Ordinals are grammar’s race numbers.

steps.line:
Practice:
• el primer día (the first day)
• la segunda casa (the second house)

lessons.title: How Talking Works — Interjections (The Small Explosions)

steps.line: Some words aren’t words at all — they’re emotions escaping the mouth. Wow! Ay! Oops! These are interjections.
Spanish common ones: ¡ay! (ouch / oh!), ¡hola! (hi!), ¡oye! (hey listen), ¡uf! (phew).

steps.origin: From Latin inter + iacere — to throw between.
steps.story: Romans literally called them 'thrown words.' Spanish still tosses them like sparks.
steps.wrap_line: Interjections are grammar’s fireworks — brief and bright.

steps.line:
Practice:
• ¡Ay! Hace frío.
• ¡Hola! ¿Cómo estás?
• ¡Uf! Estoy cansado.

lessons.title: How Talking Works — Future Plans Review (Dreams with Dates)

steps.line: Plans are tomorrow’s grammar.  When you talk about what will happen, you stretch language into hope.
Use ir a + infinitive: voy a viajar mañana.  Add time words like luego (then), pronto (soon).

steps.origin: From Latin ire ad — 'to go toward.'
steps.story: Every plan starts as motion.  Spanish still moves toward the future the Roman way.
steps.wrap_line: Future plans grammar is hope with a schedule.

steps.line:
Practice:
• Voy a estudiar mañana.
• Vamos a visitar la familia pronto.

lessons.title: How Talking Works — Memory Phrases (Looking Back Kindly)

steps.line: When you tell old stories, you use memory words: before, after, long ago.
antes (before), después (after), hace (time ago). Example: Hace dos años viví aquí.

steps.origin: From Latin ante and post — front and after.
steps.story: Time words are Roman arrows; Spanish still shoots them across memory.
steps.wrap_line: Memory grammar is yesterday bottled for today.

steps.line:
Practice:
• Antes trabajé aquí.
• Hace un año estudié mucho.

lessons.title: How Talking Works — Story Sequences (Cause and Effect)

steps.line: Stories live in motion: one thing happens, then another.  Cause meets effect through connectors.
porque (because), así que (so), entonces (then). Example: Trabajo porque quiero dinero.

steps.origin: From Latin causa and effectus.
steps.story: Logic became narrative; Spanish uses it daily.
steps.wrap_line: Sequence grammar is storytelling’s backbone.

steps.line:
Practice:
• Estudio porque tengo examen.
• Tengo hambre, así que como.

lessons.title: How Talking Works — Double Negatives (Two No’s Make It Stronger)

steps.line: In English, two negatives cancel. In Spanish, they hold hands for emphasis.
No + negative word: No tengo nada (I have nothing), No veo a nadie (I see no one).

steps.origin: From Latin 'non habeo nihil' — literally 'I do not have nothing.'
steps.story: The Romans meant double strength, not contradiction; Spanish kept the muscle.
steps.wrap_line: Double negatives are grammar’s thunder — loud but clear.

steps.line:
Practice:
• No tengo nada.
• No veo a nadie.
• No digo nunca.

lessons.title: How Talking Works — Family Words (Grammar at Home)

steps.line: Family words build belonging.  They name love and chaos equally.
madre (mother), padre (father), hermano (brother), hermana (sister), hijo/hija (son/daughter).

steps.origin: From Latin mater, pater, frater, filius.
steps.story: The oldest words survive because families keep saying them.
steps.wrap_line: Family vocabulary is grammar’s heartbeat at home.

steps.line:
Practice:
• Mi madre cocina.
• Tengo un hermano.

lessons.title: How Talking Works — Feelings & Intensity (Very and Too)

steps.line: Intensity words are emotional volume knobs: a little, very, too.
muy (very), un poco (a little), demasiado (too much). Example: Estoy muy feliz. Estoy un poco cansado.

steps.origin: From Latin multum, paucum, demasia — 'overflow.'
steps.story: Romans loved exaggeration; Spanish turned it into warmth.
steps.wrap_line: Intensity is grammar’s emotional dial.

steps.line:
Practice:
• Estoy muy bien.
• La casa es demasiado grande.

lessons.title: How Talking Works — Locations with Prepositions (Around the Room)

steps.line: To describe a place, you need where-words that pair with estar.
en (in), sobre (on), debajo (under), cerca (near), lejos (far).

steps.origin: From Latin sub, super, circa, longe.
steps.story: Geography turned into grammar long before maps existed.
steps.wrap_line: Location prepositions are grammar’s compass points.

steps.line:
Practice:
• El libro está sobre la mesa.
• El gato está debajo de la silla.

lessons.title: How Talking Works — House Words (Rooms and Things)

steps.line: The home is a dictionary in walls: room, door, table, window.
la casa (house), la puerta (door), la mesa (table), la ventana (window), la silla (chair).

steps.origin: From Latin casa, porta, mensa, fenestra, sella.
steps.story: Romans named their houses piece by piece; Spanish lives in those same sounds.
steps.wrap_line: House words are grammar’s architecture.

steps.line:
Practice:
• La mesa está en la casa.
• La puerta está abierta.

lessons.title: How Talking Works — Color & Feeling Mix (Mood Painting)

steps.line: Colors often describe feelings: blue sad, red angry. Spanish pairs them freely.
estar + color word for mood = Estoy rojo (I’m embarrassed), Estoy verde (I’m jealous/new).

steps.origin: From ancient color symbolism in Latin art.
steps.story: Romans painted feelings before psychologists named them; Spanish never stopped.
steps.wrap_line: Color feelings are grammar’s poetry shortcuts.

steps.line:
Practice:
• Estoy rojo.
• Estoy verde de sueño.

lessons.title: How Talking Works — Simple Past Actions (Stories That Ended)

steps.line: To talk about something that happened once and is over, Spanish uses the simple past, or 'preterite.'
Regular patterns: -ar → -é, -aste, -ó, -amos, -aron (hablé, trabajé); -er/-ir → -í, -iste, -ió, -imos, -ieron (comí, viví).

steps.origin: From Latin perfect endings -avi, -ui, -ii.
steps.story: They were once grand endings for epic tales; Spanish uses them for lunch stories now.
steps.wrap_line: Simple past is grammar’s campfire tense — short, bright, done.

steps.line:
Practice:
• Hablé con mi amigo.
• Comí pan.
• Viví en otra casa.

lessons.title: How Talking Works — Linking Verbs (Connecting Ideas)

steps.line: Some verbs exist only to link.  They don’t act; they connect who with what.
ser, estar, parecer — to be, to seem.  Use them to join subject and description.

steps.origin: From Latin esse, stare, and parere.
steps.story: Romans loved linking thoughts like chainmail; Spanish polished the links.
steps.wrap_line: Linking verbs are grammar’s connectors between heart and label.

steps.line:
Practice:
• Soy estudiante.
• Estoy cansado.
• Parece fácil.

lessons.title: How Talking Works — Health Phrases (Body Grammar)

steps.line: Language even checks its pulse.  Health phrases keep daily life human.
tener + noun: tengo hambre (I’m hungry), tengo sed (I’m thirsty), tengo sueño (I’m sleepy).

steps.origin: From Latin habere — 'to have.'
steps.story: Romans said 'I have hunger'; Spanish never saw a reason to change it.
steps.wrap_line: Health phrases are grammar’s body language.

steps.line:
Practice:
• Tengo frío.
• Tengo hambre.
• Tengo sueño.

lessons.title: How Talking Works — Want & Need (Desire Grammar)

steps.line: Want and need sit next to each other in the mind, but Spanish dresses them differently.
querer (to want) + noun/verb; necesitar (to need) + noun/verb. Example: quiero agua; necesito descansar.

steps.origin: From Latin quaerere and necessitas.
steps.story: Desire and need once meant 'to seek' and 'not to have.'  Spanish remembers the difference between dream and duty.
steps.wrap_line: Want/need grammar is the engine of motivation.

steps.line:
Practice:
• Quiero café.
• Necesito dormir.
Not everything is certain.  Grammar leaves room for maybe.
quizás / tal vez — maybe; puede ser — could be.  Use with present tense verbs.

steps.origin: From Latin quis sapit — 'who knows.'
steps.story: The Romans used questions to make space for doubt; Spanish turned them into gentle words.
steps.wrap_line: Possibility grammar is language breathing out instead of declaring.

steps.line:
Practice:
• Quizás llueve hoy.
• Puede ser verdad.

lessons.title: How Talking Works — Time Connectors (From Then to Now)

steps.line: Time connectors are bridges that link yesterday to tomorrow.
desde (since), hasta (until), mientras (while), cuando (when).

steps.origin: From Latin de ex and ad ista — distance and limit words.
steps.story: Ancient farmers used them to time planting; Spanish uses them to time life.
steps.wrap_line: Time connectors are grammar’s clock hands.

steps.line:
Practice:
• Trabajo desde lunes hasta viernes.
• Leo mientras como.

lessons.title: How Talking Works — Emphasis Words (Making a Point)

steps.line: Sometimes you need to underline without a pen.  Emphasis words do it for you.
solo (only), también (also), incluso (even), realmente (really).  Place them near the verb or adjective.

steps.origin: From Latin solus, tam, includere, res.
steps.story: Latin loved showing importance through position; Spanish still plays spotlight with word order.
steps.wrap_line: Emphasis grammar is verbal highlighter ink.

steps.line:
Practice:
• Solo quiero pan.
• También estudio inglés.

lessons.title: How Talking Works — Story Closers (Endings with Feeling)

steps.line: Every story needs a landing.  Grammar ends tales with gentle anchors.
al final (in the end), finalmente (finally), por fin (at last).

steps.origin: From Latin finis — boundary or limit.
steps.story: Romans respected endings.  Spanish still gives closure a word of honor.
steps.wrap_line: Story closers are grammar’s goodbye hugs.

steps.line:
Practice:
• Al final todo está bien.
• Finalmente descanso.

lessons.title: How Talking Works — Fear Phrases (Little Warnings)

steps.line: Even fear has grammar.  It whispers caution through set phrases.
tener miedo de — to be afraid of; cuidado — careful; peligro — danger.

steps.origin: From Latin metus and periculum.
steps.story: Romans built cities and still feared storms.  Their fear words survived the empire.
steps.wrap_line: Fear phrases are grammar’s safety rails.

steps.line:
Practice:
• Tengo miedo de la oscuridad.
• Cuidado con el perro.

lessons.title: How Talking Works — Celebration Phrases (Joy Grammar)

steps.line: Happiness speaks fast and loud.  Spanish joy has short, bright grammar.
¡Felicidades! (congratulations), ¡Salud! (cheers), ¡Qué bueno! (how nice!).

steps.origin: From Latin felix — happy, healthy.
steps.story: Latin believed happiness was luck; Spanish turned it into sharing.
steps.wrap_line: Celebration grammar is sunshine you can say.

steps.line:
Practice:
• ¡Felicidades por tu día!
• ¡Salud y alegría!

lessons.title: How Talking Works — Everyday Small Talk (The Social Warm-Up)

steps.line: Small talk keeps language alive between big thoughts.  It oils the gears of conversation.
¿Cómo estás? (How are you?), ¿Qué tal? (How’s it going?), Todo bien. (All good.)

steps.origin: From Latin talis — 'such'— everyday softness.
steps.story: Even Romans needed filler words at dinner; Spanish perfected them.
steps.wrap_line: Small talk is grammar’s handshake before meaning.

steps.line:
Practice:
• ¿Qué tal?
• Todo bien, gracias.

lessons.title: How Talking Works — Repetition (Echo for Emphasis)

steps.line: Repeating a word is the oldest trick in speech — it makes rhythm and feeling.
Use reduplication for emotion: poquito a poquito (little by little), día tras día (day after day).

steps.origin: From Latin poetic repetition — incantations of emphasis.
steps.story: Echo was once divine; Spanish keeps her alive in idioms.
steps.wrap_line: Repetition is grammar’s heartbeat drum.

steps.line:
Practice:
• Poco a poco aprendo.
• Día tras día trabajo.

lessons.title: How Talking Works — Community Words (Together Grammar)

steps.line: No one speaks alone.  Language was born in groups, and Spanish names them kindly.
amigo (friend), gente (people), familia (family), equipo (team).

steps.origin: From Latin amicus, gens, familia, excipere.
steps.story: The first words ever spoken were probably for kin and tribe.  Spanish still begins there.
steps.wrap_line: Community words are grammar’s open arms.

steps.line:
Practice:
• Mi familia es grande.
• Tengo muchos amigos.

lessons.title: How Talking Works — Feelings Review (Heart Vocabulary)

steps.line: Before moving to harder grammar, we revisit feelings — the real first language.
Use estar + adjective: estoy feliz, estoy triste, estoy cansado.

steps.origin: From Latin ad-jectum — 'thrown toward' nouns.
steps.story: Adjectives stick to us like moods; Spanish lets them move freely.
steps.wrap_line: Feelings grammar is the pulse under every verb.

steps.line:
Practice:
• Estoy feliz.
• Estoy triste.
• Estoy cansado.

lessons.title: How Talking Works — Future Predictions (Guessing Ahead)

steps.line: Prediction is the playful cousin of planning — 'I think it will…' turns grammar into guessing.
Simple future endings: -é, -ás, -á, -emos, -án.  Example: hablaré, comeré, viviré.

steps.origin: From Latin infinitive + habere — 'to have to.'
steps.story: Romans invented the future by promising.  Spanish still keeps its hope in the ending.
steps.wrap_line: Future predictions are grammar’s fortune-telling tent.

steps.line:
Practice:
• Comeré mañana.
• Viviré cerca del mar.
Conditionals build imaginary worlds: if this, then that.
si + present → future or command: Si llueve, no salgo.  Si estudias, aprendes.

steps.origin: From Latin condicio — agreement, situation.
steps.story: Ancient philosophers used 'if' to test logic; Spanish uses it to plan days.
steps.wrap_line: Conditionals are grammar’s daydream switch.

steps.line:
Practice:
• Si tengo tiempo, leo.
• Si hace sol, camino.

lessons.title: How Talking Works — Final Review Patterns (Everything Together)

steps.line: All grammar pieces now dance together — nouns, verbs, colors, times, and feelings.
Model sentence: El amigo feliz estudia en la casa porque quiere aprender.

steps.origin: From the medieval Latin artes grammaticae — the crafts of speaking well.
steps.story: To medieval teachers, mastery meant weaving every thread into one cloth.
steps.wrap_line: Final review is grammar’s quilt — all patterns stitched tight.

steps.line:
Practice:
• La familia trabaja en casa y está contenta.
• El día es largo pero bueno.
A micro-story is three lines: who, what, feeling.  Grammar becomes heartbeat narrative.
Start with ayer / hoy; add verb + reason + feeling.

steps.origin: From Latin micro + historia — 'small history.'
steps.story: Every language trains memory through tiny stories; Spanish makes them sing.
steps.wrap_line: Micro-stories are grammar’s postcards from life.

steps.line:
Practice:
• Hoy trabajo, como y descanso. Estoy feliz.

lessons.title: How Talking Works — Polite Endings (Kind Closures)

steps.line: Goodbyes need grammar too.  Spanish closes talk gently.
Adiós (goodbye), hasta luego (see you later), buenas noches (good night), cuídate (take care).

steps.origin: From Latin ad deum — 'to God,' and cura te — 'care for yourself.'
steps.story: Ancient farewells carried blessings; Spanish still does.
steps.wrap_line: Polite endings are grammar’s bow before silence.

steps.line:
Practice:
• Buenas noches.
• Hasta luego.
• Cuídate.

lessons.title: How Talking Works — Reflection (Why We Speak)

steps.line: At the end of grammar, we realize it was never about rules.  It was about connection.
Grammar = pattern + feeling + memory.  Spanish shows it through sound and warmth.

steps.origin: From Greek gramma — letter, and logos — reason.
steps.story: The word grammar once meant 'the knowledge of letters.'  It has always been a mirror of thought.
steps.wrap_line: Reflection is grammar seeing itself and smiling.

steps.line:
Practice:
• Hablo para vivir.
• Aprendo para hablar.

lessons.title: How Talking Works — Farewell (The Full Circle)

steps.line: We began by pointing at things and naming them.  Now we can tell stories, share days, and say goodbye.
Review of all: nouns, verbs, adjectives, prepositions, time, emotion, connectors.

steps.origin: From Latin circulus — a ring, a loop.
steps.story: All learning is a circle.  Spanish, like life, loops back to the start — naming what we love.
steps.wrap_line: Farewell is grammar’s thank-you note to the learner.

steps.line:
Practice:
• Gracias por aprender.
• Nos vemos pronto.
Public. Audience.
‘Público’ refers to general people or those watching a show.

steps.origin: From Latin ‘publicus’.
steps.story: Opposite of private; also the group that reacts.
steps.wrap_line: ‘Público’ is eyes gathered together.

steps.line: El público aplaude fuerte.
Art museum.
‘Museo de arte’ is a place that exhibits paintings, sculptures, and media.

steps.origin: From Greek ‘Mouseion’ (Muses) + Latin ‘ars’.
steps.story: A home for preserved imagination.
steps.wrap_line: ‘Museo de arte’ is memory and beauty under one roof.

steps.line: El museo de arte abre hoy.
